Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating the potential of carbon-14 in polar firn and ice as a tracer of past cosmic ray flux and an absolute dating tool
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work will investigate the potential of carbon-14 in ice cores as an absolute dating tool, as a tracer of the past cosmic ray flux and as a recorder of the past fossil fraction of the global methane budget. Cosmic ray particles produce carbon-14 from oxygen-16 directly within near-surface glacial ice and firn. This in-situ produced carbon-14 quickly reacts to form 14C-containing carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and methane in the ice matrix. Some or all of the resulting 14C-bearing gases may be lost from the firn to the atmosphere. The proposed work will provide a thorough characterization of in-situ cosmogenic 14C in glacial firn and shallow ice in the Summit region of Greenland. It will examine the retention of cosmogenic 14C in ice grains at all depth levels in the firn column, the partitioning of 14C between carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and methane, as well as the production rates and accumulation of cosmogenic 14C in shallow ice below firn close-off. A thorough understanding of cosmogenic C-14 in firn and shallow ice will likely enable the use of C-14 in ice for one or more of the following applications: 
1) If a relatively large amount of cosmogenic 14C is present in ice below the depth at which air bubbles become sealed off, it will be useful as a tracer for past cosmic ray flux. The investigators believe that this is the likely case for 14C-carbon monoxide.
2) If the amount of retained in-situ-produced 14C-carbon dioxide is relatively small compared to 14C-carbon dioxide from trapped air, the study will demonstrate the validity of using 14C-carbon dioxide for absolute dating of ice cores; this has long been a target of ice core studies.
3) If the amount of retained in-situ-produced 14C-methane is relatively small compared to 14C-methane from trapped air, the study will demonstrate the validity of using 14C-methane in glacial ice for determinations of the fossil fraction of the past methane budget, including releases from methane clathrates.
The proposed work will establish a new international collaboration between University of Rochester (UR) and University of Bern and result in novel laboratory and field analytical systems. The data from the study will be made available to the scientific community and the broad public through the ACADIS data service. One graduate student will be trained at UR, and one postdoc and one graduate student will be partially supported at Oregon State University. Three UR undergraduates will be involved in fieldwork and research. The work will support an early career scientist. All of the investigators will continue to participate in public outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project's main aim was to improve scientific understanding of carbon-14 that is produced in snow and ice in the polar ice caps by cosmic rays ("in situ cosmogenic 14C"). Carbon-14 is a radioactive isotope of carbon that is produced by cosmic rays both in the Earth's atmosphere and at the surface. In glacial ice of the polar ice caps, carbon-14 originates both from inclusion of air into bubbles (when snow gradually transforms into ice) and from direct production in the ice grains. Carbon-14 in glacial ice can potentially serve in a number of useful applications in the earth sciences. However, given the low level of understanding of in situ cosmogenic 14C prior to this project, none of these applications were possible.

The project was successful in all of its major aims. Three logistically complex field campaigns were conducted at Greenland Summit, retrieving large air samples from the deep snowpack as well as very large (about 2000 lbs each) samples of the compacted snow (called "firn") from the top 240 ft of the ice sheet, and similarly large samples of solid glacial ice from below. 14C is present in the snow and ice primarily in the forms of  carbon dioxide (14CO2), carbon monoxide (14CO) as well as methane (14CH4).  At the time of writing of this report, all planned measurements of 14CO and 14CH4 have been successfully completed, and one final set of measurements of 14CO2 is still in progress. During the course of the project, a state-of-the-art new analytical system was developed for extraction of trapped air from ≈3 lb samples of ice for subsequent 14CO2 analyses.

The results are still in the interpretation stage, but the following is already clear from the preliminary data:

1) Very little of the in situ cosmogenic 14C that is produced by cosmic rays in the firn grains actually stays in the firn grains. The vast majority of this 14C (about 98%) appears to rapidly escape into the firn air space.

2) The amount of in situ cosmogenic 14C that is produced deeper down where firn transitions to solid ice is relatively small. For 14CH4 and 14CO2, the  amount of 14C from in situ cosmogenic production is much smaller than the amount that is included in the ice via trapping of air. For 14CO, the amount from in situ cosmogenic production  appears to be larger than the amount that is included in the ice via trapping of air.

These results have several important implications. First, it means that measurements of 14CO2 in deeper, older ice from the polar regions can potentially be used for establishing the ages of this ice or for improving the atmospheric 14CO2 history (also known as the "radiocarbon calibration curve", which is used very widely in geosciences and archaeology), depending on the site.

Second, it appears that 14CO can be useful for either reconstructions of past cosmic ray flux and past solar activity, or reconstructions of past atmospheric chemistry, depending on the site. Both of these applications would  be of great interest in the geosciences.

Finally, the results suggest that 14CH4 at most ice coring sites can be used to study the fraction of the atmospheric methane that comes from fossil sources. This can help with separating natural and anthropogenic fossil methane emissions,  as well as with improving the understanding of the likelihood of large natural methane emissions from old carbon sources (such as permafrost and methane stored in the form of hydrate in ocean sediments) in response to future warming.

The project contributed wholly or partially to the scientific training of 6 PhD students, 4 undergraduate students, 1 postdoc and 2 technicians. Results of the work have been shared with the scientific community at several professional conferences. The project also included active communication of our results to the general public and educating the public about the nature of our work. This included public lectures, school visits (or connecting with schools remotely from Greenland via Skype), interviews on the local public radio station, an "ask a scientist" table at a local farmers market,  as well as an educational blog about polar fieldwork.
